concepts.concept_name: States of matter: solid, liquid, gas
Properties of matter: physical and chemical

in_scope: Matter: anything that has mass and occupies space
Three states of matter: solid, liquid, gas
Properties of solids: definite shape and volume
Properties of liquids: definite volume, no definite shape
Properties of gases: no definite shape or volume
Physical properties: color, odor, density, melting point, boiling point
Chemical properties: reactivity, combustibility
Melting, freezing, evaporation, condensation
Sublimation: solid to gas directly
out_of_scope: Kinetic theory of matter — Introduced in Class 8
Plasma state — Introduced in Class 10
Latent heat calculations — Introduced in Class 9

concepts.concept_name: Atoms and molecules in elements and compounds

in_scope: Atom: smallest particle of an element
Molecule: smallest particle of a substance with independent existence
Atoms combine to form molecules
Monoatomic, diatomic, polyatomic molecules
Examples of diatomic molecules: H2, O2, N2, Cl2
Examples of polyatomic molecules: P4, S8, O3
Molecules of compounds: H2O, CO2, NH3
Difference between atoms and molecules
out_of_scope: Atomic structure (subatomic particles) — Introduced in Class 8
Electronic configuration — Introduced in Class 8
Dalton's atomic theory details — Introduced in Class 8

in_scope: Pure substances have fixed composition
Elements: cannot be broken down further
Classification of elements: metals and non-metals
Properties of metals: lustrous, malleable, ductile
Properties of non-metals: dull, brittle, poor conductors
Compounds: formed by chemical combination
Properties of compounds differ from constituent elements
Mixtures: homogeneous and heterogeneous
Separation methods: filtration, evaporation, distillation
out_of_scope: Metalloids — Introduced in Class 8
Detailed separation techniques — Introduced in Class 8
Chemical bonding — Introduced in Class 9

concepts.concept_name: Differences between physical and chemical changes

in_scope: Physical change: no new substance formed
Physical change: usually reversible
Examples: melting, boiling, dissolving, breaking
Chemical change: new substance formed
Chemical change: usually irreversible
Examples: rusting, burning, cooking, digestion
Indicators of chemical change: color change, gas evolution, heat change
Reversible changes: can be undone
Irreversible changes: cannot be undone
out_of_scope: Detailed classification of changes — Introduced in Class 8
Conditions for chemical reactions — Introduced in Class 8
Chemical equations — Introduced in Class 8

in_scope: Acids: sour taste, turn blue litmus red
Common acids: HCl, H2SO4, HNO3, vinegar, citric acid
Bases: bitter taste, soapy feel, turn red litmus blue
Common bases: NaOH, KOH, Ca(OH)2, ammonia
Indicators: substances that show color change
Litmus: red and blue litmus paper
Natural indicators: turmeric, red cabbage juice
Phenolphthalein and methyl orange
Neutralization: acid + base = salt + water
out_of_scope: pH scale — Introduced in Class 8
Strong and weak acids/bases — Introduced in Class 8
Ionic dissociation — Introduced in Class 9

in_scope: Metals: lustrous, malleable, ductile, good conductors
Examples of metals: iron, copper, aluminium, gold, silver
Non-metals: dull, brittle, poor conductors
Examples of non-metals: carbon, sulfur, oxygen, nitrogen
Exceptions: mercury (liquid metal), graphite (conducting non-metal)
Reaction of metals with oxygen: formation of metal oxides
Reaction of metals with water
Reaction of metals with acids
Uses based on properties
out_of_scope: Metalloids — Introduced in Class 8
Reactivity series — Introduced in Class 8
Ionic and covalent compounds — Introduced in Class 9

concepts.concept_name: Properties and uses of gases in air

in_scope: Air is a mixture of gases
Nitrogen: 78%, Oxygen: 21%, other gases: 1%
Other gases: carbon dioxide, water vapor, noble gases
Properties of oxygen: supports combustion
Properties of nitrogen: does not support combustion
Properties of carbon dioxide: turns lime water milky
Air pollutants: CO, CO2, SO2, NO2, particulates
Sources of pollution: vehicles, industries, burning
Effects: respiratory problems, acid rain, global warming
Prevention: reduce emissions, use clean fuels, plant trees
out_of_scope: Detailed greenhouse effect — Introduced in Class 8
Ozone layer depletion — Introduced in Class 8
Industrial processes — Introduced in Class 10

in_scope: Water: colorless, odorless, tasteless liquid
Boiling point: 100 degrees Celsius, Freezing point: 0 degrees Celsius
Water as universal solvent
Solutions: solute, solvent, solution
Saturated and unsaturated solutions
Suspensions: particles settle down
Water cycle: evaporation, condensation, precipitation
Importance of water for life
Water conservation
out_of_scope: Anomalous expansion of water — Introduced in Class 8
Hard and soft water — Introduced in Class 8
Water of crystallization — Introduced in Class 8

in_scope: Chemical symbols: one or two letter representation
Symbols from Latin names: Fe, Cu, Ag, Au, Na, K
Common element symbols: H, O, C, N, S, P, Cl
Valency: combining capacity of an element
Valency of common elements: H(1), O(2), N(3), C(4)
Writing simple formulas using valency
Common formulas: H2O, CO2, NaCl, CaCO3
Meaning of subscripts in formulas
out_of_scope: Variable valency — Introduced in Class 8
Molecular formula writing in detail — Introduced in Class 8
Balancing equations — Introduced in Class 8

in_scope: Chemical reaction: process where new substances are formed
Reactants and products
Word equations for simple reactions
Combination reactions: A + B gives AB
Decomposition reactions: AB gives A + B
Examples: burning of magnesium, rusting of iron
Exothermic reactions: release heat
Endothermic reactions: absorb heat
Examples of everyday chemical reactions
out_of_scope: Symbol equations — Introduced in Class 8
Balancing chemical equations — Introduced in Class 8
Displacement reactions — Introduced in Class 8
